instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.SMC_BC_OK: What is SMC_BC_OK? This is a typo of SMC_BC_ACOK When you see SMC_BC_OK, assume they meant to type SMC_BC_ACOK.
definitions.R7121: What is R7121? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7122: What is R7122? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7152: What is R7152? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Runs only if SMC bypass
threads.message:
I've been working on this board for some time now. It was slightly water damaged and had no green light and was missing some rails.

I changed the SMC and have green light and all my power rails. CPU gets warm. Fan spins for 8 seconds, off for 4 seconds, and on for 4 seconds, and will turn back on and stay on.

<CHIP>U7200</CHIP> was hit the worst. Had to make jumpers and changed the chip. <CAPACITOR>C6950</CAPACITOR> & <CAPACITOR>C6951</CAPACITOR> hit with blown vias. <CHIP>U5810</CHIP> pin 10 corroded and switched with one from <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. <CHIP>U5660</CHIP> pins 4 & 5 have a little corrosion but left alone; seems ok.

I have tried a couple SMCs and get the same results.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Runs only if SMC bypass
threads.message: So is my thinking correct that I should check the data lines on page 40?

threads.message: Check <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> sense resistors and traces.

threads.message:
No Title

16.7 on <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R7122</RESISTOR>
8.57 on <RESISTOR>R7150</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R7152</RESISTOR>
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_OK</SIGNAL> = 3.3

And what does the "BC" in <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_OK</SIGNAL> stand for?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Runs only if SMC bypass
threads.message: Run ASD to check for sensor errors. Check if audio device is detected in OSX. All audio circuits are on the DC board, so replace that including the cable.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Runs only if SMC bypass
threads.message:
No Title

Says SMC maybe the issue.  I have put like 4 different SMCs on here the pads are starting to widen with the coated traces and probably combining together. Or may be the SMC itself. The area looks around it and have checked it dozens of times.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Runs only if SMC bypass
threads.message: Tony, run the ASD, your board most likely has a current sense issue.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Runs only if SMC bypass
threads.message: Run EFI ASD, not the internal useless shit.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Runs only if SMC bypass
threads.message:
What is the correct ASD for Early 2014 13" Macbook air? Most lists do not have it listed, one on github lists 3S156 which most others list for 2013 only. Is the link posted accurate? Also having a hard time finding any newer than 156.

Downloaded ASD 3S156 found on an old thread here and it boots into ASD but a message pops up stating it is the wrong machine.

<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> EMC 2632 Serial # C02L40LDF5V7

The readme only lists 2013.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Runs only if SMC bypass
threads.message:
The error you have now is most likely a bad trackpad cable/trackpad/connector. Inspect for corrosion

3S156 is the last ASD that would run on an Air so yours can only run AST2 which is not going to happen.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Runs only if SMC bypass
threads.message: I do not have trackpad cable connected.  Would no cable connected cause high fan spin?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Runs only if SMC bypass
threads.message: Well yeah.....

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Runs only if SMC bypass
threads.message:
Really?! No trackpad connected will cause high fan spin?  I didn't know that !  Yes, problem solved!

QUESTION: So to refer back to current sensing, that takes place at <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R7122</RESISTOR> correct? Or, there are more areas for current sensing? And anything connected to the SMC that has an issue can cause high fan spin as well, ie camera, battery, trackpad?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Runs only if SMC bypass
threads.message: Anything connected to SMBUS can mess with temp. sensors and cause high fan spin. Without trackpad you will always have high fan on ANY macbook.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Runs only if SMC bypass
threads.message: Rodger that Duke !   THANK YOU !!!!
